page.title: 09ENMORE SCHOOL
page.content: Enmore National School was one of the first free elementary schools in the country.It was founded in 1810 by the Rev. John Poole, Rector of Enmore. He used the 'Monitorial System' under which the older children (monitors) taught the rest under the supervision of a teacher. He also introduced the teaching of English grammar and Arithmetic which was unusual at that time. By 1812 the monitorial system was widely known in the area. John Poole applied successfully for a grant to build a bigger school in Enmore. By 1837 plans were drawn up for the present building to be erected on land donated by the Earl of Egmont. The total cost was estimated at two hundred and seventy-seven pounds. With few alterations to the south-facing front the buildings remain the same today as they were in Poole's time.
